case.sLatestTextSummary: Rather than registering a ton of Handlebar Helper functions to help with the rendering of data that gets returned to the Loadr widget, I propose that we add a "parse" method before the data gets passed to the template. This parse method would allow ...
case.sTitle: We need the ability to parse data that is returned from the server using Loadr (et al)

event.sHtml:
Rather than registering a ton of Handlebar Helper functions to help with the rendering of data that gets returned to the Loadr widget, I propose that we add a "parse" method before the data gets passed to the template. This parse method would allow us to transform and format the data as well as add new fields to the data response based on the business logic that each implementation requires.

Here's the implementation that I came up with for CCC.  It allows a string reference to the function name to be passed in a custom data attribute (eg, 'data-cs-parse="CRIMSON.MeasureDashboard.parse"') or an actual function to be passed if called from the Javascript (eg, "$('.class').loadr({ parse: function(data){ ... } });"). The bolded section is the code I added to the "_success" method.

$.crux.loadr.prototype.options.parse = null;
$.crux.loadr.prototype._success = function (results, status, jxhr) {
    if (this.options.replace === true) {
        this.options.target.empty();
    }

    this._vars.resultsData = results;

   if (this.options.allresults === false && results.Results === undefined) {   
       this._error(jxhr, 'parseerror', 'error');
       return;
   }

   if ((this.options.allresults === true && !results.length) || (this.options.allresults === false && !results.Results.length)) {
       this._error(jxhr, 'nodata', 'error');
       return;
   }

   if (this.options.parse) {
       if (typeof this.options.parse === "string") {
           var parser = CRUX.stringToFunction(this.options.parse);
           results = parser(results);
       } else if (typeof this.options.parse === "function") {
           results = this.options.parse(results);
       } else {
           this._error(jxhr, 'parseerror', 'error');
       }
   }

   if (this.options.template && this._processOutput === undefined) {
       this.options.target.append( this._vars.template( this.options.allresults ? results : results.Results ) );
   } else if (this._processOutput) {
      this._processOutput();
   }

   this._trigger('success', null, results);
   this._vars.success.fireWith(this, [this.element[0], results]);
};

case.sTitle: Main Navigation indicator is not a smooth triangle in Safari

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Alex Bilstein by Alex Bilstein

event.s: The triangular indicator looks jagged in Safari. Can we make this a smooth triangle?

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Jay Morrow by Alex Bilstein
event.sHtml: The triangular indicator looks jagged in Safari. Can we make this a smooth triangle?

event.sChanges: Project changed from 'Market Advantage' to 'CrUX'. Area changed from 'Look and Feel' to 'Boilerplate'. Milestone changed from '2012.06.Sonata: 7/13/2012' to 'Boilerplate 1.2.3: 7/6/2012'. Removed tags 'UX-Issues', 'CrUX'. Parent changed from Case 42901 to (None).

event.s:
Hey Alex,
The triangle in the nav is created by styling the bottom border of an element with zero height and width. Here's a visual aid:
Safari and IE8 don't seem to do anti-aliasing of border miters which is what's causing the jagged appearance. If the angle of the miter is 45deg, then anti-aliasing is not necessary. If the angle is adjusted to overcome this issue, the triangle will be slightly taller. Here's a screenshot for comparison:
The only other solution I can think of is to use a background image instead of a styled border. But images aren't so cool anymore.
So, if you (and your fellow designers) don't like the jagged look and are ok with making the triangle a few pixels taller, I say we go with that solution. Thoughts?
Marcus
event.sChanges: Notified Jay Morrow. Area changed from 'Boilerplate' to 'Design'.
event.evtDescription: Assigned to Alex Bilstein by Marcus Ellis
event.sHtml:
Hey Alex,

The triangle in the nav is created by styling the bottom border of an element with zero height and width.  Here's a visual aid:

Safari and IE8 don't seem to do anti-aliasing of border miters which is what's causing the jagged appearance.  If the angle of the miter is 45deg, then anti-aliasing is not necessary.  If the angle is adjusted to overcome this issue, the triangle will be slightly taller.  Here's a screenshot for comparison:

The only other solution I can think of is to use a background image instead of a styled border.  But images aren't so cool anymore.

So, if you (and your fellow designers) don't like the jagged look and are ok with making the triangle a few pixels taller, I say we go with that solution.  Thoughts?

Marcus

event.s:
Marcus,
This is what I'm seeing now:
And if I'm not mistaken, it's looked that way for a while now. I assumed this had been fixed at some point. Maybe newer versions of Safari handle the aliasing properly? When I filed the case, I don't believe that 6 was available yet. Note to self - include browser version in case notes.
Can you reproduce the original issue? What version of Safari? If you can, and it's only jaggy in older versions of Safari, then I say we close the case and move on as this will only affect a small number of users and it will eventually go away on its own.
event.evtDescription: Assigned to Marcus Ellis by Alex Bilstein

event.s:
Alex,
I was able to reproduce the issue on Mac & PC using Safari 5.1.7. Safari 6 may have improved anti-aliasing support, but I believe it is only currently available for OS X Lion and Mountain Lion. So Safari users on older versions of OS X or other operating systems will still see the jagged triangle.
Also, IE8 produces the seem jagged appearance which probably impacts a large number of our users (especially on the CCA side).
Marcus

case.sLatestTextSummary: This is being corrected with the removal of the custom scrollbars.

event.s:
In cs.scrollr.js, find the private method '_positionY'. Notice this._trigger('y',...) is invoked every time the y position is computed. This is not necessarily a healthy behavior because when the developer requires setting the y callback after init, the callback is fired.
Also notice callbacks are fired when x/y positions are not computed (or doesn't seem that should be) e.g. when no action is taken by the user.
event.sHtml:
In cs.scrollr.js, find the private method '_positionY'. Notice this._trigger('y',...) is invoked every time the y position is computed. This is not necessarily a healthy behavior because when the developer requires setting the y callback after init, the callback is fired.

Also notice callbacks are fired when x/y positions are not computed (or doesn't seem that should be) e.g. when no action is taken by the user.

case.sLatestTextSummary: An issue was found where it is only possible to search on the default sortcolumn. BugzId 54194 To reproduce the bug go to https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkA/Reports and select any standard report. Once the report loads switch the sort column ...
case.sTitle: Searching on grid resets sortcolumn and sortdirection

event.s:
An issue was found where it is only possible to search on the default sortcolumn. BugzId 54194
To reproduce the bug go to https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkA/Reports and select any standard report. Once the report loads switch the sort column and execute a search.
The result is a reset to the default sortcolumn and the ability to only search on that column.
A fix was added to resolve this in the CMA cruxUpdate.js by extending the crux.loadr _create method and calling reload instead of reset at line 36. This is line 264 in the cs.loadr.js.
event.sHtml:
An issue was found where it is only possible to search on the default sortcolumn. BugzId 54194

To reproduce the bug go to https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkA/Reports and select any standard report. Once the report loads switch the sort column and execute a search.

The result is a reset to the default sortcolumn and the ability to only search on that column.

A fix was added to resolve this in the CMA cruxUpdate.js by extending the crux.loadr _create method and calling reload instead of reset at line 36. This is line 264 in the cs.loadr.js.

case.sLatestTextSummary: There's some weird behavior going on with $.dialog. In CMA, we use the beforeClose callback to display an "Are you sure you want to close?" message that currently only behaves correctly because of a workaround. To see this, go to ...

event.s:
There's some weird behavior going on with $.dialog. In CMA, we use the beforeClose callback to display an "Are you sure you want to close?" message that currently only behaves correctly because of a workaround. To see this, go to https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkA/Opportunities/Initiatives, click Create a New Initiative, change some fields and click the X to see the confirmation. The workaround to make this behave correctly is located in Content/app/js/common/cs.cruxUpdates.js where Manny created an new option for $.dialog called beforeClose_patch.
The problem occurs at line 5842 of jquery-ui.custom.js. self._trigger('beforeClose') returns undefined instead of the expected boolean value. Here's where I get stuck. I've tested the following to be relatively sure this is a CrUX issue:
- Remove CMA from the equation: go to the CrUX API site, make a new div in the DOM, initialize it with $.dialog and add a beforeClose option to return false. This should stop you from being able to close the dialog, but it doesn't.
- Remove jQuery UI from the equation: I made a JSFiddle (http://jsfiddle.net/VzTQx/) and copied the exact jQuery UI source from CrUX as well as the specific CMA dialog call. Here, beforeClose functions correctly.
I'm not finding anywhere in CrUX where dialog or beforeClose is extended/modified other than cs.jquery.js where some global dialog options are set, and commenting those out doesn't fix the issue.
event.sHtml:
There's some weird behavior going on with $.dialog. In CMA, we use the beforeClose callback to display an "Are you sure you want to close?" message that currently only behaves correctly because of a workaround. To see this, go to https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkA/Opportunities/Initiatives, click Create a New Initiative, change some fields and click the X to see the confirmation. The workaround to make this behave correctly is located in Content/app/js/common/cs.cruxUpdates.js where Manny created an new option for $.dialog called beforeClose_patch.

The problem occurs at line 5842 of jquery-ui.custom.js. self._trigger('beforeClose') returns undefined instead of the expected boolean value. Here's where I get stuck. I've tested the following to be relatively sure this is a CrUX issue:

- Remove CMA from the equation: go to the CrUX API site, make a new div in the DOM, initialize it with $.dialog and add a beforeClose option to return false. This should stop you from being able to close the dialog, but it doesn't.

- Remove jQuery UI from the equation: I made a JSFiddle (http://jsfiddle.net/VzTQx/) and copied the exact jQuery UI source from CrUX as well as the specific CMA dialog call. Here, beforeClose functions correctly.

I'm not finding anywhere in CrUX where dialog or beforeClose is extended/modified other than cs.jquery.js where some global dialog options are set, and commenting those out doesn't fix the issue.

event.s:
When creating a new user in user admin, nearly the moment you start typing in the email address field you will get a warning to enter an email address. This warning is coming far too soon, it should be delayed more.

event.s:
Reassigning this to the CrUX team.
Devin had a nice suggestion on an alternative to the error message. Instead of showing a "red" error box, show a friendlier "yellow" info box with a tip on formatting.
The other approach might be to bind only specific events to a particular element by using a data-cs-event attribute (or whatever). For example, we might not want to validate an e-mail address until the field loses focus, so the element could be initialized as such:
<input type="email" data-cs-event="blur" ... />
Of course since type="email" triggers e-mail validation anyway then this can all be handled behind the scenes assuming that the consensus is to handle e-mail validation when the field loses focus.
Yet another approach is to provide access to a public method where we can invoke validators explicitly when making use of the "customCheck" functionality.

Reassigning this to the CrUX team.

Devin had a nice suggestion on an alternative to the error message. Instead of showing a "red" error box, show a friendlier "yellow" info box with a tip on formatting.

The other approach might be to bind only specific events to a particular element by using a data-cs-event attribute (or whatever). For example, we might not want to validate an e-mail address until the field loses focus, so the element could be initialized as such:

<input type="email" data-cs-event="blur" ... />

Of course since type="email" triggers e-mail validation anyway then this can all be handled behind the scenes assuming that the consensus is to handle e-mail validation when the field loses focus.

Yet another approach is to provide access to a public method where we can invoke validators explicitly when making use of the "customCheck" functionality.

case.sTitle: CRuX Grid CSS not friendly to embedded tables

event.s: I am embedding tables within a CRuX Grid cell. However, because cs-grid.css applies certain styles to any embedded tags, not just the first level, the embedded grids are styled just like the main Grid. This is undesirable, and overriding this styling is proving to be challenging.
event.sHtml: I am embedding tables within a CRuX Grid cell. However, because cs-grid.css applies certain styles to any embedded tags, not just the first level, the embedded grids are styled just like the main Grid. This is undesirable, and overriding this styling is proving to be challenging.

case.sTitle: Multi-list option list needs style improvements

event.s:
When an option list label wraps to two lines, the line-height makes the text too far apart, and the text wraps under the checkbox. Perhaps adding more top and bottom padding instead of using the line-height to create space would help.
Also, the label ideally wouldn't wrap under the checkbox.
I fixed this for the first version of CrUX CMA, but I'll need to redo it during the 2.0 upgrade. This is just documentation for that change in a ticket I should have made earlier.
event.sHtml:
When an option list label wraps to two lines, the line-height makes the text too far apart, and the text wraps under the checkbox.  Perhaps adding more top and bottom padding instead of using the line-height to create space would help.

Also, the label ideally wouldn't wrap under the checkbox.

I fixed this for the first version of CrUX CMA, but I'll need to redo it during the 2.0 upgrade.  This is just documentation for that change in a ticket I should have made earlier.

case.sLatestTextSummary: Looks good:
case.sTitle: Grid bulk counter positioning is off when headers wrap

event.s: The bulk counter is not positioned correctly if any of the headers wrap to two lines, like in CMA's Targets page (https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkB/Opportunities/Targets). It displays high above the bulk action button, likely because it is being absolutely positioned relative to the entire table, not the table cell.
event.sHtml: The bulk counter is not positioned correctly if any of the headers wrap to two lines, like in CMA's Targets page (https://dtest.crimsonservices.com/trunkB/Opportunities/Targets). It displays high above the bulk action button, likely because it is being absolutely positioned relative to the entire table, not the table cell.

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Henry Clark by Paul Clark

event.s:
Here's the issue: the bulk counter is positioned absolute to its containing element, div.cs-grid-body, which is fine when the column description text is all on one line. But when the text expands to two lines, it increases the size of the <th> cells which pushes up the height of the containing div:
I've experimented with setting other containers as the relative ancestor, but none are satisfactory since they adversely affect other grid elements. I'm assigning this to Jay since I fear this will require either re-architecting or some sort of JavaScript detection for setting a non-single-line height.
In the meantime a temporary solution for CMA would be to target the grid on this page and adjust the .cs-grid-bulk-count div to "top: 0;".
event.sChanges: Developer changed from Aamir Salman to Henry Clark Tester changed from Aamir Salman to Paul Clark Code Reviewer changed from Aamir Salman to Jay Morrow Status changed from 'New' to 'Assigned'. Estimate set to '16 hours'
event.sHtml:
Here's the issue: the bulk counter is positioned absolute to its containing element, div.cs-grid-body, which is fine when the column description text is all on one line. But when the text expands to two lines, it increases the size of the <th> cells which pushes up the height of the containing div:

 

I've experimented with setting other containers as the relative ancestor, but none are satisfactory since they adversely affect other grid elements. I'm assigning this to Jay since I fear this will require either re-architecting or some sort of JavaScript detection for setting a non-single-line height.

In the meantime a temporary solution for CMA would be to target the grid on this page and adjust the .cs-grid-bulk-count div to "top: 0;".

event.sHtml: I'm not able to reproduce this.  Here's what I see.

event.s:
Jay, I think this may be a CrUX issue.
We were finally able to reproduce it - this apparently only happens on screens roughly 27" or larger. You can replicate it on two smaller screens if you stretch the window across both screens. The drop downs appear as though they are being sized relative to the viewport, not to the content area.

case.sTitle: Add Documentation for enabled/disabled methods on widgets

event.s:
The jQuery UI Widget factory provides the default option of 'disabled' and the default methods of 'enable' and 'disable'.
We need to add these to the documentation in cs.base.js.
event.sHtml:
The jQuery UI Widget factory provides the default option of 'disabled' and the default methods of 'enable' and 'disable'.

We need to add these to the documentation in cs.base.js.

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Henry Clark by Jay Morrow

event.s: Got the methods easy enough but not sure how we should handle documenting the default option: should it be a @param for the @method option, or as a @property inside a function like _getCreateOptions?
event.evtDescription: Assigned to Jay Morrow by Henry Clark
event.sHtml: Got the methods easy enough but not sure how we should handle documenting the default option: should it be a @param for the @method option, or as a @property inside a function like _getCreateOptions?

event.s: The parameters should follow the same pattern as the other widgets. Let's take a few minutes today to go over it.

case.sLatestTextSummary: Not actually needed

event.s:
We have a number of widgets/files that wait for DOM ready to initialize. We really don't need that many DOM ready functions in our applications, we also need to handle the case where async scripts may be returned before other resources.
Create a wrapper that will allow us to queue multiple functions that are waiting on DOM ready. Once the DOM is ready fire the collection of callbacks.
In the case where a script is loaded and the DOM is already 'ready',you should invoke the function immediately without adding it to the queue.
Add this to the the Boilerplate, not the Widgets.
event.sHtml:
We have a number of widgets/files that wait for DOM ready to initialize. We really don't need that many DOM ready functions in our applications, we also need to handle the case where async scripts may be returned before other resources.

Create a wrapper that will allow us to queue multiple functions that are waiting on DOM ready. Once the DOM is ready fire the collection of callbacks.

In the case where a script is loaded and the DOM is already 'ready',you should invoke the function immediately without adding it to the queue.

Add this to the the Boilerplate, not the Widgets.

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Jay Morrow by Jay Morrow

case.sTitle: Allow selectr objects to resize with the browser window

event.s: The selectr objects used in the CMA Initiatives landing page are not resizing with the browser window. It looks like a width calculation is done when the page loads, then it stays that width until the page refreshes. It also appears that if two selectrs are next to each other, like they are on the Initiatives page, there isn't the usual gutter between them. Here's the HTML:
event.sHtml:
The selectr objects used in the CMA Initiatives landing page are not resizing with the browser window.  It looks like a width calculation is done when the page loads, then it stays that width until the page refreshes.

It also appears that if two selectrs are next to each other, like they are on the Initiatives page, there isn't the usual gutter between them.

Here's the HTML:

<div class="filters row">
    <select id="selectDateRange" class="col3">
        <option value="1" selected="selected">Show All Initiatives</option>
        <option value="2">Current Initiatives</option>
        <option value="3">Past Initiatives</option>
        <option value="4">Future Initiatives</option>
    </select>
    <select id="selectSort" class="col3">
        <option value="LastEditedOn" selected="selected">Modified Date</option>
        <option value="CreatedOn">Created Date</option>
        <option value="Title">Title</option>
        <option value="PhysicianCount">Number Of Physicians</option>
        <option value="VisitReportCount">Visit Reports</option>
    </select>
</div>

case.sLatestTextSummary: IE7 is taking a long time to render with the boxsizing.htc fix. Improve performance here. The columns are not respecting the min and max-width that is set. Add some scripts to check for breakpoints to ensure the columns are being held to their ...

event.s:
IE7 is taking a long time to render with the boxsizing.htc fix. Improve performance here.
The columns are not respecting the min and max-width that is set. Add some scripts to check for breakpoints to ensure the columns are being held to their correct sizes.
event.sHtml:
IE7 is taking a long time to render with the boxsizing.htc fix. Improve performance here.

The columns are not respecting the min and max-width that is set. Add some scripts to check for breakpoints to ensure the columns are being held to their correct sizes.

case.sLatestTextSummary: Replace current success callback with _success: function (results, status, jxhr) { if (this.options.replace === true) { this.options.target.empty(); } this._vars.resultsData = results; if (this.options.allresults === false && results.Results ...

event.sHtml:
Replace current success callback with

        _success: function (results, status, jxhr) {
            if (this.options.replace === true) {
                this.options.target.empty();
            }

            this._vars.resultsData = results;

            if (this.options.allresults === false && results.Results === undefined) {
                this._error(jxhr, 'parserror', 'error');
                return;
            }

            if ((this.options.allresults === true && !results.length) || (this.options.allresults === false && !results.Results.length)) {
                this._error(jxhr, 'nodata', 'error');
                return;
            }

            if (this.options.template && this._processOutput === undefined) {
                this.options.target.append(this._vars.template(this.options.allresults ? results : results.Results));
            } else if (this._processOutput) {
                this._processOutput();
            }

            /**
            @name Loadr#loadrsuccess
            @event
            @description <p>Triggered after an successful server response from an ajax request where there is data.</p>
                <pre class="brush: js">
                $('.example').bind( "loadrsuccess", function(event) {});
                </pre>
            */
            this._trigger('success', null, results);
            this._vars.success.fireWith(this, [this.element[0], results]);
        },

case.sLatestTextSummary: Changes make sense to me.

event.s:
Having a large number elements using Loadr on the same page at the same time can cause slowdown and potential crashing in older version of IE.
Two solutions:
1. Only display loading functionality if the element is visible when loading in data.
2. Use a standard animated gif instead of a canvas/vml solution for older brwosers.
event.sHtml:
Having a large number elements using Loadr on the same page at the same time can cause slowdown and potential crashing in older version of IE.

Two solutions:

1. Only display loading functionality if the element is visible when loading in data.

2. Use a standard animated gif instead of a canvas/vml solution for older brwosers.

case.sLatestTextSummary: Add two helpers to the Boilerplate that get loaded with Handlebars. each_index - Will iterate over the array of items and add a member of _index to the object. This way we can add logic to our other helpers based on the index of the item. ...

event.s:
Add two helpers to the Boilerplate that get loaded with Handlebars.
each_index - Will iterate over the array of items and add a member of _index to the object. This way we can add logic to our other helpers based on the index of the item.
insert_row - A helper to add rows to results templates when there are two many results for a single row.
event.sHtml:
Add two helpers to the Boilerplate that get loaded with Handlebars.

each_index - Will iterate over the array of items and add a member of _index to the object. This way we can add logic to our other helpers based on the index of the item.

insert_row - A helper to add rows to results templates when there are two many results for a single row.

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Jay Morrow by Jay Morrow

case.sLatestTextSummary: Added (stroke) next to the check icons in the documentation
case.sTitle: Check icon documentation or code is incorrect

event.s: When I define the following: and I get the X icon instead of a check. I looked at the boilerplate page and saw that the check requires iconic-stroke even though stroke is not in the class name. So it would be up to you guys whether you'd add stroke to the class name as the documentation suggests or remove the stroke requirement. Also, shouldn't I just get nothing if I define it incorrectly instead of getting an unexpected icon? I'll add "stroke" in the meantime, and Alex might not even want the check in the final design, so this isn't major. Thanks.
event.sHtml:
When I define the following:

<i class="iconic check"></i>

and I get the X icon instead of a check. 

I looked at the boilerplate page and saw that the check requires iconic-stroke even though stroke is not in the class name.  So it would be up to you guys whether you'd add stroke to the class name as the documentation suggests or remove the stroke requirement.  Also, shouldn't I just get nothing if I define it incorrectly instead of getting an unexpected icon?

I'll add "stroke" in the meantime, and Alex might not even want the check in the final design, so this isn't major.

Thanks.

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Jay Morrow by Jeanette Silvas

case.sLatestTextSummary: === GOAL === When search field autocomplete is working, replace the clear field button "X" with an animated "Searching" graphic, like a spinner, as per design comp. === ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA === 1. When user enters text into search field and ...
case.sTitle: Add "searching" spinner graphic to search field

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Henry Clark by Henry Clark

event.s:
=== GOAL === When search field autocomplete is working, replace the clear field button "X" with an animated "Searching" graphic, like a spinner, as per design comp.
=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA === 1. When user enters text into search field and autocomplete starts, clear field button "X" disappears and is replaced with spinner graphic 2. Autocomplete finishes search, spinner graphic disappears, clear field button "X" reappears and results menu displays 3. If no results are returned, spinner graphic disappears and clear field button "X" reappears
=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS === 1) Enter text (suggested: "tho") into search field 2) Observe results 3) Clear results, enter new text that will not be found (suggested: "xx") 4) Observe results
=== OPEN QUESTIONS === None.
=== TECHNICAL NOTES === None.
event.sChanges: Developer changed from (None) to Henry Clark Tester changed from (None) to Jay Morrow Code Reviewer changed from (None) to Jay Morrow Estimate set to '6 hours'
event.sHtml:
=== GOAL ===
When search field autocomplete is working, replace the clear field button "X" with an animated "Searching" graphic, like a spinner, as per design comp.

=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA ===
1. When user enters text into search field and autocomplete starts, clear field button "X" disappears and is replaced with spinner graphic
2. Autocomplete finishes search, spinner graphic disappears, clear field button "X" reappears and results menu displays
3. If no results are returned, spinner graphic disappears and clear field button "X" reappears

=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS ===
1) Enter text (suggested: "tho") into search field
2) Observe results
3) Clear results, enter new text that will not be found (suggested: "xx")
4) Observe results

=== OPEN QUESTIONS ===
None.

=== TECHNICAL NOTES ===
None.

=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA === 1) Data source conforms to JSON pattern established in CrUX Ajaxloader, namely: [code] { TotalRecords: 1, Results: [0:{ label: "Thomas Collier", category: "Patients" }] } [/code]

=== TECHNICAL NOTES === None.

Data handling for search conforms to CrUX standard.

=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA ===
1) Data source conforms to JSON pattern established in CrUX Ajaxloader, namely:
[code]
{
    TotalRecords: 1,
    Results: [0:{ label: "Thomas Collier", category: "Patients" }]
}
[/code]

=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS ===
1) Inspect code in cs.search.js

=== OPEN QUESTIONS ===
None.

=== TECHNICAL NOTES ===
None.

case.sLatestTextSummary: === GOAL === Search results dropdown menu conforms to design spec and has requested functionality === ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA === 1) Supports Section labels (Patient, Provider, etc.) 2) Mouse over highlights each result 3) Clicking on result enters ...

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Henry Clark by Henry Clark

event.s:
=== GOAL === Search results dropdown menu conforms to design spec and has requested functionality
=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA === 1) Supports Section labels (Patient, Provider, etc.) 2) Mouse over highlights each result 3) Clicking on result enters result data into input field 4) Limit number of displayed results to ten, show total results in bottom field 5) If possible, underline portions of result text corresponding to input text
=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS === 1) Enter text into search field (currently limited data set names starts with "T") 2) Results menu appears, total results should appear in bottom 3) Mouse over results and select one 4) Selected result appears in search input box
=== OPEN QUESTIONS === Re: #5, not sure if that's feasible, will research.
=== TECHNICAL NOTES === Criteria 4 may depend on Data API subcase.
event.sChanges: Developer changed from (None) to Henry Clark Tester changed from (None) to Jay Morrow Code Reviewer changed from (None) to Jay Morrow Estimate set to '8 hours'
event.sHtml:
=== GOAL ===
Search results dropdown menu conforms to design spec and has requested functionality

=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA ===
1) Supports Section labels (Patient, Provider, etc.)
2) Mouse over highlights each result
3) Clicking on result enters result data into input field
4) Limit number of displayed results to ten, show total results in bottom field
5) If possible, underline portions of result text corresponding to input text

=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS ===
1) Enter text into search field (currently limited data set names starts with "T")
2) Results menu appears, total results should appear in bottom
3) Mouse over results and select one
4) Selected result appears in search input box

=== OPEN QUESTIONS ===
Re: #5, not sure if that's feasible, will research.

=== TECHNICAL NOTES ===
Criteria 4 may depend on Data API subcase.

case.sLatestTextSummary: This case only covers the actual search field, I'm moving on to the results menu and the data case. Please let me know where I can minimize/simplify/reduce/improve/etc.
case.sTitle: Search field opening and closing animation

event.evtDescription: Assigned to Henry Clark by Henry Clark

event.s:
=== GOAL === Search field opens on mouse click, closes on clicking elsewhere on screen, open and close is animated using CSS3 with jQuery UI fallback.
=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA === 1) Search field opens on clicking magnifying glass icon 2) Search field opening animates smoothly and in a way that is acceptable to design 3) Search field closes when clicking outside of field or results menu dropdown 4) Uses CSS3 transition for modern browsers and jQuery UI animation for older browsers
=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS === Be sure to test fallback on versions of IE.
=== OPEN QUESTIONS === None.
=== TECHNICAL NOTES === Update to Modernizr library to support CSS3 transition detection.
event.sChanges: Project changed from 'Core Platform' to 'CrUX'. Area changed from 'Misc' to 'Boilerplate'. Estimate set to '6 hours'
event.sHtml:
=== GOAL ===
Search field opens on mouse click, closes on clicking elsewhere on screen, open and close is animated using CSS3 with jQuery UI fallback.

=== ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA ===
1) Search field opens on clicking magnifying glass icon
2) Search field opening animates smoothly and in a way that is acceptable to design
3) Search field closes when clicking outside of field or results menu dropdown
4) Uses CSS3 transition for modern browsers and jQuery UI animation for older browsers

=== TESTING INSTRUCTIONS ===
Be sure to test fallback on versions of IE.

=== OPEN QUESTIONS ===
None.

=== TECHNICAL NOTES ===
Update to Modernizr library to support CSS3 transition detection.
